facts.text: This is a petition by the assessee under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the companystitutionality of the second proviso to s. 10 2 vi-b of Income tax Act introduced by The Taxation Laws Amendment Act 28 of 1960

anchor.surface_text: -This is a petition by the assessee under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the companystitutionality of the second proviso to s. 10 2   vi-b  of Income tax Act introduced by The Taxation Laws  Amendment  Act  28 of 1960 .

facts.text: Petitioner is a limited companypany with its registered office at Madurai in the State of Madras

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a limited companypany with its registered office at Madurai in the State of Madras which owns a fleet of buses and lorries and carries on the business of transport

anchor.surface_text: which owns a fleet of buses and lorries and carries on the business of transport

facts.text: Petitioner carries on the business of transport

anchor.surface_text: and carries on the business of transport In respect of assessment year 1960-61 it claimed a development rebate on all its plants and machinery including business.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of assessment year 1960-61 it claimed a development rebate on all its plants and machinery including business.

facts.text: Income tax Officer disallowed the claim of rebate on transport vehicles under the proviso

anchor.surface_text: The Income tax Officer disallowed the claim of rebate on transport vehicles under the proviso above quoted and companyputed the tax payable without such rebate.

facts.text: Income tax Officer companyputed the tax payable without such rebate

anchor.surface_text: and companyputed the tax payable without such rebate.

facts.text: It was companytended on behalf of the petitioner that the proviso offends Art. 14 in that it discriminates between machinery which is office appliance or road transport vehicles and other kind of machinery

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the petitioner that the proviso offends Art. 14 in that it discriminates between machinery which is office appliance or road transport vehicles and other kind of machinery.

facts.text: The petition is wholly without merit and is therefore dismissed and the rule is discharged

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to accept such a companytention because there is numberhing in the Constitution which prevents the legislature from choosing the object of taxation from amongst various classes of machinery for the purpose of giving development rebate. The Constitution does number prohibit any such classification which has been made in the pressnt case. The petition is wholly without merit and is therefore dismissed and the rule is discharged.

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that no allowance under this clause shall be made in respect of any machinery or plant which consists of office appliances or road transport vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 14

concepts.interpretation: Not violated by classification in tax rebate proviso as legislature may select classes of machinery for incentives
Classification distinguishing road transport vehicles/office appliances from other machinery is permissible for granting development rebate

issues.text: Whether the second proviso to s. 10(2)(vi-b) of the Income Tax Act offends Article 14 of the Constitution in that it discriminates between machinery which is office appliance or road transport vehicles and other kind of machinery

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the petitioner that the proviso offends Art. 14 in that it discriminates between machinery which is office appliance or road transport vehicles and other kind of machinery.

arguments.claim: The proviso offends Art. 14 in that it discriminates between machinery which is office appliance or road transport vehicles and other kind of machinery

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the petitioner that the proviso offends Art. 14 in that it discriminates between machinery which is office appliance or road transport vehicles and other kind of machinery.

arguments.court_reasoning: Nothing in the Constitution prevents the legislature from choosing objects of taxation from amongst various classes of machinery for development rebate; Constitution does not prohibit such classification.

arguments.claim: There is nothing in the Constitution which prevents the legislature from choosing the object of taxation from amongst various classes of machinery for the purpose of giving development rebate; the Constitution does not prohibit any such classification which has been made in the present case

holdings.text: there is nothing in the Constitution which prevents the legislature from choosing the object of taxation from amongst various classes of machinery for the purpose of giving development rebate. The Constitution does not prohibit any such classification which has been made in the present case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature permitted to select classes of machinery for development rebate incentives; no constitutional bar to such classification under Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: The petition is wholly without merit and is therefore dismissed and the rule is discharged.

outcome.relief_summary: The petition is dismissed and the rule is discharged as it is wholly without merit.

edges.explanation: Argument directly addresses the issue by claiming the proviso discriminates in violation of Art. 14

The argument that there is nothing in the Constitution preventing the legislature from choosing classes of machinery directly supports the concept that CONST_ART14 is not violated by such classification for incentives.
The argument provides the grounds for the holding, as both state identical reasoning that the Constitution does not prevent legislative selection of machinery classes for development incentives.
The argument addresses the issue of whether the proviso discriminates under Article 14 by asserting legislative power to select classes of machinery.
The concept that CONST_ART14 is not violated by the classification directly addresses the issue of whether the proviso offends Article 14.
The reasonable classification doctrine grounds the holding permitting legislative classification of road transport vehicles/office appliances from other machinery for development purposes.
The doctrine of reasonable classification under Article 14 twin test addresses the issue of whether the proviso to s. 10(2)(vi-b) discriminates between types of machinery, violating Article 14.

edges.explanation: f17 provides the exact statutory text of the second proviso that constitutes and satisfies the concept c9

The holding that there is nothing preventing the legislature from choosing objects of taxation among classes of machinery grounds the concept that CONST_ART14 is not violated by the classification in the tax rebate proviso.
The holding defends the legislature's classification under the proviso to Section 10(2)(vi-b) as constitutionally permissible, supporting the validity of the concept.
Holding upholds legislature's power to classify machinery for development rebate, supporting valid classification excluding office appliances and road vehicles in c9
The holding that the legislature may classify machinery for development rebate purposes addresses the issue of Article 14 violation by the proviso.
